problem: A rectangular prism has a base area of 120 cm^2 and a height of 15 cm. If a smaller rectangular prism that is similar to the larger one has a height of 10 cm, what is the volume of the smaller prism? Give the answer in decimal and round to 2 decimal places.
solution: Since the smaller prism is similar to the larger prism, the ratio of corresponding linear dimensions is 10:15 or 2:3. Thus, the base area of the smaller prism is \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^2 of the larger base area, which is \left(\frac{4}{9}\right) \times 120 \text{ cm}^2 = 53.333 \text{ cm}^2. The volume of the smaller prism is base area \times height = 53.333 \text{ cm}^2 \times 10 \text{ cm} = 533.33 \text{ cm}^3. \(\boxed{533.33}\)
